title: Hydroponic Farming Without Electricity: Best Passive Systems

tasks.task: Setting up a Kratky hydroponic system
subtasks: Prepare the nutrient solution by filling a wide-mouthed container with water and mixing in hydroponic nutrients according to instructions
Adjust the pH of the nutrient solution to the appropriate level (5.5-6.5) for the chosen plants
Plant seedlings or young plants into net cups filled with suitable growing medium (e.g., coconut coir or rockwool)
Ensure the net cups are submerged in the nutrient solution, leaving an air gap at the base to allow roots access to oxygen
Place the system in a location with at least 6 hours of sunlight per day, or provide supplemental grow lights if necessary
Monitor nutrient solution levels and top up as required to maintain consistent moisture and nutrient supply
Change the nutrient solution every 2-3 weeks to prevent salt buildup and maintain plant health

tasks.task: Caring for a Kratky hydroponic garden
subtasks: Ensure adequate sunlight (at least 6 hours per day) or use grow lights
Keep pH within optimal range (5.5-6.5) and regularly check/adjust using a pH testing kit
Maintain good air circulation around the system to prevent mold and mildew
Monitor plant growth and health, adjusting the system as needed based on observations
Address common issues like lighting inadequacy, nutrient deficiencies, pH imbalances, and poor air circulation by applying troubleshooting solutions

tasks.task: Building a wick-based passive hydroponic system (e.g., Kratky method)
subtasks: Collect and prepare a wide-mouthed container for the nutrient solution
Source and prepare net cups or similar containers for holding plants
Choose and prepare appropriate growing medium (e.g., coconut coir, rockwool)
Obtain suitable seedlings or young plants for hydroponic growth (e.g., lettuce, herbs)
Assemble the system by combining the container, net cups, growing medium, and nutrient solution
Ensure correct submersion and positioning of the net cups within the solution
Position the system in a suitable location with adequate light

tasks.task: Comparing Passive vs. Active Hydroponic Systems
subtasks: Acknowledge the affordability and low maintenance of passive hydroponic systems
Recognize the higher costs and ongoing electricity needs of active systems involving pumps, timers, and grow lights

tasks.task: Exploring benefits and applications of Passive Hydroponics
subtasks: Highlight water conservation, reduced involvement with soil and pests, and ease of setup and maintenance
Note the suitability for small-scale, sustainable farming and urban gardening
Identify alternative methods such as floating rafts and clay pebble beds
Understand the versatility for growing various crops (e.g., leafy greens, herbs, tomatoes) depending on the system
Emphasize the low entry barrier for beginners and potential for scalability and innovation
